your own Interpretation. We know
it, however, by its more popular
name Halloween.


During the past years indivi-
dually and group sponsored pro-
grams we're designed to take
some of the mischief and pranks
out of the celebration. Positive
approaches toward sharing Holt
day funds with children of the
United Nations is worthwhile.
Sponsors of school or church car
nivals have added more fun to the
sea son.


But Saturday = all day lacked
much of the old spirit of Hal
loween. 1t seems that many of
the customs we are losing in our
climb to being a sophisticated
and cultured society leaves
many empty spaces.


Trick or treat has merely
given children license to ring
the doorbell and hold out bags
for candy or gum. Too many
older youths visited our home.
Many we're not bedecked in color
full costume or even ma sked.


The streets we're not filled
with the shouts of merrymakers
or pranksters. No mail box on
our block wa disturbed. There
we're no clangings of garbage
cans. There were soapywindows.
There were not pots of red paint
thrown at any driveway around us.


What has happened to the
COLLINS, ghosts and wicked
witches who once roamed on
every Halloween Who has seen
real live Satan lately7 Surely
one man still is brave enough
to parade in a skintight union
suit as the thin man or his
fat brother7 Where are the
girls who like to resemble
Chinese, Arabian or even Latin
beauties7


| didn't see one jack O. lantern
in a window l heard no one
SIX for some cider and ginger
snaps. | saw no young ones
bobbing for apples.


There were two young mothers
accompanying their small chill
dren in our neighborhood = they
at lea st are working to keep the
spirit of Halloween alive.


| am saddened when | realize
that many parent keep their chill
dren off the streets at night be-
cause of fear. am unhappy
when we hear of some mentally
disturbed women pa ssing out rat
poisons and insect killers for
treats.


The greatest shock of the entire
Halloween sea son was bitter
blow. One of our neighbors
grew some pumpkins and not
pumpkin was carried off for
a decoration or eating.


Just for fun, | let my magma
tion run wild and | created four
bulletin board decorations for
my eighth grade room. Their
smiles of approval gave me
enough hope that all children
still like some fanta sy.


Our Nancy, the witch, was
ia shioned from black construc-
tion paper and discarded mop,
donated by our custodian. Her
green lips, three yellow teeth
and a red wart on her nose,
brought outlaws from the older
pupils, but a few primary viewers
we're frightened.


Our best board was spooky
ghost, dubbed Lothario. The
white sheet, black eyes with yell
low centers, made the hit parade
when our young visitors filed
pas st.


We tried TO canture a bit of
